content: I am only starting to recognize the equivalence between displayed and indexed stuff shows up in many places, and I am a beginner in the yoga of the Grothendieck construction. I am writing about an equivalence between relations valued in a complete lattice and families of binary relations indexed by that lattice, and I was wondering what is the quickest way to see it as Grothendieck construction. Let me give the gist very briefly, with some more details here.

Let LLL be a complete lattice.

Definition: An LLL-relation on a set XXX is a function d:X×X→Ld: X\times X \to Ld:X×X→L with no additional constraint.
Definition: An LLL-structure on a set XXX is a continuous functor R:L→P(X×X)R: L \to \mathcal{P}(X\times X)R:L→P(X×X), we see both LLL and the powerset P(X×X)\mathcal{P}(X\times X)P(X×X) as posetal categories (the order of the latter is the inclusion).
Proposition: There is a correspondence between LLL-relations and LLL-structures on XXX.

Definition: The category LRelsL\mathbf{Rel}_sLRels​ has sets equipped with an LLL-relation as objects, and a morphism f:(X,d)→(Y,Δ)f: (X,d) \to (Y,\Delta)f:(X,d)→(Y,Δ) is a function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y satisfying d(x,x′)=Δ(f(x),f(x′))d(x,x') = \Delta(f(x),f(x'))d(x,x′)=Δ(f(x),f(x′)).
Defintion: The category LStrsL\mathbf{Str}_sLStrs​ has sets equipped with an LLL-structure as objects, and a morphism f:(X,R)→(Y,S)f: (X,R) \to (Y, S)f:(X,R)→(Y,S) is a function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y satisfying f(Re)=Sef(R_e) = S_ef(Re​)=Se​ for all e∈Le \in Le∈L. You can probably see it as some comma category L↓P(−×−)L \downarrow \mathcal{P}(-\times -)L↓P(−×−).
Proposition: The categories LRelsL\mathbf{Rel}_sLRels​ and LStrsL\mathbf{Str}_sLStrs​ are isomorphic.

Definition: The category LRelL\mathbf{Rel}LRel has sets equipped with an LLL-relation as objects, and a morphism f:(X,d)→(Y,Δ)f: (X,d) \to (Y,\Delta)f:(X,d)→(Y,Δ) is a function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y satisfying d(x,x′)≥Δ(f(x),f(x′))d(x,x') \geq \Delta(f(x),f(x'))d(x,x′)≥Δ(f(x),f(x′)).
Defintion: The category LStrL\mathbf{Str}LStr has sets equipped with an LLL-structure as objects, and a morphism f:(X,R)→(Y,S)f: (X,R) \to (Y, S)f:(X,R)→(Y,S) is a function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y satisfying f(Re)⊆Sef(R_e) \subseteq S_ef(Re​)⊆Se​ for all e∈Le \in Le∈L. You can probably see it as some lax or colax comma category L↓P(−×−)L \downarrow \mathcal{P}(-\times -)L↓P(−×−).
Proposition: The categories LRelL\mathbf{Rel}LRel and LStrL\mathbf{Str}LStr are isomorphic.
To reiterate my question: Are these propositions simple corollaries of a known result ?
How are an L-relation and an L-structure equivalent?

They seem different from what you expect a Grothendieck construction to identify. A Grothendieck construction would send X×X→LX \times X \to LX×X→L to E→XE \to XE→X, where the latter has to be interpreted suitably (i.e. as an L-functor of sorts)
Your correspondence reminds me more of the equivalence between H-sets and H-sheaves for a Heyting algebra H

Maybe I got the wrong feeling about it being a Grothendieck construction then. I actually have an isomorphism between LRelL\mathbf{Rel}LRel and LStrL\mathbf{Str}LStr proven in the file above. On objects we have:

So this is not an H-sets/H-sheaves correspondence
I'm leaning towards a combination of (1) a general correspondence between functions A→PBA \to PBA→PB and B→PAB \to PAB→PA and (2) the fact that a complete lattice has a PPP-algebra structure

Indeed, given a function L→P(X×X)L \to P(X \times X)L→P(X×X) one has a corresponding 'transpose' X×X→PLX \times X \to PLX×X→PL. Postcomposing the latter with inf⁡:PL→L\inf : PL \to Linf:PL→L yields the L-relation in the second picture.
I didn't use the fact the L-structure is continuous though

Viceversa, transposing an L-relation gives you L→P(X×X)L \to P(X \times X)L→P(X×X) but this sends ϵ\epsilonϵ to the subset of X×XX \times XX×X of those pairs related by precisely ϵ\epsilonϵ. You probably pass to the downsets to get the continuity..?
